title: Max and Mod
statementHtml:
You are given an integer nn. Find any permutation pp of length nn∗∗ such that:

If it is impossible to find such a permutation pp, output −1−1.

∗∗A permutation of length nn is an array consisting of nn distinct integers from 11 to nn in arbitrary order. For example, [2,3,1,5,4][2,3,1,5,4] is a permutation, but [1,2,2][1,2,2] is not a permutation (22 appears twice in the array), and [1,3,4][1,3,4] is also not a permutation (n=3n=3 but there is 44 in the array).

††xmodyxmody denotes the remainder from dividing xx by yy.
inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤991≤t≤99). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains a single integer nn (2≤n≤1002≤n≤100).
outputSpecHtml:
For each test case:

  • If such a permutation pp doesn't exist, output a single integer −1−1.
  • Otherwise, output nn integers p1,p2,…,pnp1,p2,…,pn — the permutation pp you've found. If there are multiple answers, output any of them.
noteHtml:
In the first test case, it is impossible to find such a permutation pp, so you should output −1−1.

In the fourth test case, p=[1,5,2,3,4]p=[1,5,2,3,4] satisfies the condition:

  • For i=2i=2, max(p1,p2)=5max(p1,p2)=5 and 5mod2=15mod2=1.
  • For i=3i=3, max(p2,p3)=5max(p2,p3)=5 and 5mod3=25mod3=2.
  • For i=4i=4, max(p3,p4)=3max(p3,p4)=3 and 3mod4=33mod4=3.
  • For i=5i=5, max(p4,p5)=4max(p4,p5)=4 and 4mod5=44mod5=4.
tutorialHtml:
When n is odd, we can construct p=[n,1,2,…,n−1]. In this case:

  • For i=2, max(p1,p2)=n and nmod2=1.
  • For i≥3, max(pi−1,pi)=i−1 and (i−1)modi=i−1.

It can be proven that there is no solution when n is even. Clearly, n cannot be placed at p1,p2, or pn. If n is placed in position 3∼n−1, let x be the position of n, then we have max(px−1,px)=max(px,px+1)=n.

Thus, there must exist an even number 2≤i≤n such that max(pi−1,pi)=n and it must satisfy max(pi−1,pi)modi=i−1. However, an even number modulo another even number can never yield an odd result, leading to a contradiction.

Time complexity: O(n) per test case.
